howCoachingWorks.title: How coaching works
howCoachingWorks.intro: Our practice follows the ICF Code of Ethics. You set the agenda; we co-design experiments that grow insight without over-promising results.

items.title: Start with a fit call
items.description: A 20-minute bilingual conversation to understand your context, language preferences, and what respectful support looks like.

items.title: ICF-aligned sessions
items.description: 50–60 minute sessions in English, Traditional Chinese, or both. We listen, question, and surface patterns that inform experiments.

items.title: Small experiments between sessions
items.description: You choose practical steps to test. We review what you learned, adjust the approach, and decide together what rhythm you need next.

items.title: Bilingual space

items.title: Context on UK work and Chinese culture

items.title: Ethics, privacy, and boundaries
items.description: ICF-aligned agreements, confidentiality, and clear scope keep coaching supportive without promising outcomes we cannot control.

faqIntro: Here’s how we keep coaching ethical, culturally aware, and practical for the transitions you’re navigating.

faqs.question: What does ICF-aligned coaching look like here?
faqs.answer: We work to the International Coaching Federation Code of Ethics: you stay in charge of the agenda, we design clear agreements, and every tool or observation is used with your permission.

faqs.question: Which languages can we use?
faqs.answer: We coach in English and Traditional Chinese, switching whenever it helps you express nuance or process cultural context.

faqs.question: Do you give advice?
faqs.answer: We stay non-directive. When useful, we may offer reflections or frameworks, and you decide how to adapt them into your experiments.

faqs.question: How many sessions will we plan?
faqs.answer: Many clients begin with 4–6 sessions. We review progress frequently and you choose whether to extend, pause, or conclude.

faqs.question: Is coaching the same as therapy or counselling?
faqs.answer: No. Coaching is forward-looking and doesn’t diagnose or treat. If therapy seems more suitable, we will signpost other services respectfully.

faqs.question: What happens between sessions?
faqs.answer: We agree on small experiments or reflections you will try. You own the actions; we meet again to learn from what happened.
